SUMMER RESEARCH PROGRAM: AI Xperience 
Emoryâ€™s Center for AI Learning invites students toÂ apply to AI.Xperience, its summer applied research program.Â In this program, students will have the opportunity to grow their data science and programming skills with hands-on learning. To be selected, students need to:Â·
	â€¢	Have been enrolled in classes in the spring 2025 semester and be enrolled at Emory in the fall 2024 semester
	â€¢	Attend 3 or 4 team meetings per week
	â€¢	Be able to commit roughly 20 hours per week to the project over the 6-week period
	â€¢	Have knowledge of common statistical analysis and machine learning methods
	â€¢	Have experience programming in R and/or PythonAll interested students should applyÂ by 11:59 PM on March 29, 2025.Â We look forward to reviewing your applications!

APPLICATIONS ARE OPEN TO JOIN THE QTM DEPARTMENT AMBASSADORS TEAM Â FOR AY 2025 - 26.Â  
Â 
QTM Ambassadors are a selective cohort of sophomores, juniors, and seniors who are committed to service and leadership in the QTM community. As the department's student representatives, Ambassadors will engage with our external advisory board, assist with programming, andÂ cultivate professional skills and relationships that will prove to be valuable long after graduation.
Â 
Here are a few requirements and opportunities:
Â 
	â€¢	Must be a QTM major or QTM minor
	â€¢	Must have a strong sense of responsibility
	â€¢	Must be available to meet on Fridays for 1 hour at least twice a month between the hours of 3:00 PM â€“ 4:30 PM
	â€¢	Network with external partners
	â€¢	Support faculty and staff with QTM events
	â€¢	Build your professional portfolio 
	â€¢	For more requirements and opportunities, Â see QTM website : https://quantitative.emory.edu/opportunities/ambassadors.html

ANNOUNCEMENT
Â 
Message for rising seniors who may be interested in applying for our CMBC Undergraduate Fellowship.
Â The Center for Mind, Brain, and Culture invites undergraduates to apply for our interdisciplinary research fellowship.Â  This fellowship provides undergraduate researchers with intellectual and professional development opportunities through participation in the vibrant, interdisciplinary intellectual community of the Center.
Â 
Students awarded the CMBC undergraduate fellowship will:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Participate in regular networking lunches
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Interact with CMBC graduate certificate students and core facultyÂ Â 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Enjoy special access to CMBC events and visiting scholars
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Be eligible to request up to $500 in funding for interdisciplinary research and/or conference participation
Â Students apply in the spring of their junior year for award in the senior year.Â  The fellowship is yearlong, beginning at
the start of the fall semester and running through the last day of spring classes.Â  Priority will be given to students 
conducting researchÂ (literature or data based; e.g. honors projects, research partners, and independent studies) 
in an area relevant to mind, brain, or culture.
Â 
Eligibility
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Eligible applicants include all Emory undergraduate students
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Applicants must be in their junior year seeking senior year fellowship support
Application Deadline - Monday, April 28, 2025Â  (last day of classes)
Notification Date - Thursday, May 1, 2025Â 
Â Â 
Additional details and instructions for application submission may be found on our website.Â 
Â 
If you have further questions about the application process, please contactÂ 
CMBC Program Coordinator, Tamara Beck.Â

ANOUNCEMENT
Â 
Â 
The priority deadline to apply to be a STEM mentor for Georgia Science Education Initiative's (GSEI)Â summer Data Detective program is this Friday! If you are staying on campus over the summer, 
this is a great opportunity to gain volunteer hours, work with middle school students, and connect
with Winship faculty.
Â 
GSEI is led by Dr. Theresa Gillespie of Winship Cancer Institute and runs STEM outreach programs
that aim to provide meaningful health and data science education in the classroom and in the community.Â The programs are supported by the National Institutes of Health, National Institutes of 
General Medicine Sciences, and the NIH Office of Data Science Strategy through a Science Education Partnership Award Grant (R25GM146271).
Â 
GSEI's Data Detectives Summer AcademyÂ offers middle school girls a unique opportunity to explore real cancer data and tackle community health challenges using Big Data, Artificial Intelligence, and biomedical research. The program will be held at Emory University June 2-6 and July 14-18, 2025, from 9 AM to 3 PM daily.Â Participants will attend engaging lectures from Emory Winship faculty, work closely with STEM mentors, and gain hands-on experience in data science and epidemiology. STEM mentors will help run small-group discussions and workshops.
Â 
Apply here: https://www.ga-science.org/dd-stem-mentors-sign-up
Â 
Address any questions to info@ga-science.org
Â 
Â 
See attached flyer for details
Â 
Â

ANOUNCEMENT FOR GRADUATING SENIORS
Â 
The Institute for Research in the Social Sciences (IRISS) at Stanford runs a program for recent undergraduate degree recipients who want to participate in social science research projects. Political Science faculty will lead several of the projects, and faculty from other departments will offering other opportunities (for details, click here).
Â 
In addition to the goal of advancing research, the IRiSS Predoctoral Research Fellowship Program is intended to:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  create opportunities for predocs to deepen their knowledge of social science topics and methods, learn about options for advanced study, and build mentoring relationships to help launch their careers; andÂ 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  diversify the pipeline into academia and industry.
Applications for these one-year and two-year paid research fellowship positions are now being accepted. We would be grateful for your help in informing your graduating seniors and recent students with bachelorâ€™s degrees about this new opportunity.
Â 
Submitted by Dr. Joe Sutherland

socializing sessions. Build valuable relationships, share experiences, and explore potential collaborations in a relaxed and friendly environment.

Data Science for Social Good 
Data Science for Social Good is happening on February 23rd at the Emory Student Center! This exciting event will explore the intersection between data science and affordable housing in Atlanta.Â 
Â 
Join us for a day of expert-led talks and a hands-on data science workshop to uncover insights on the affordable housing issue in Atlanta and across the country. You'll hear from data scientists and housing experts on biased algorithms in housing, Georgia's eviction crisis, and how to empower social change using data science and analytics. A professional data analyst also guide you through a geospatial mapping and regression modeling workshop using real housing data. Free food will be provided for all attendees!Â

ANNOUNCEMENT
Â 
Â 
Hi Sociology students â€” the below message from Dr. Simonds of GSU may be of interest....Â 
Â 
The Gerontology Institute at GSU offers an intimate, nurturing, and stimulating environment in which to learn. Information on our programs can be found here.Â For detailed information on program requirements and courses, please see our Graduate Student Handbook.Â 
Â 
The 36-credit MA in GerontologyÂ leads to stableÂ employment for our graduates,Â who go on to serveÂ older adults through employment in direct service, governmental, and non-governmental organizations.Â  ApproximatelyÂ one-fourth go on to earn PhDs in Gerontology, Sociology, and other related fields.Â 
Â 
We admit students for the MA program once a year to begin in the Fall term.Â TheÂ deadline for Fall 2025 MA applications is March 1.Â Â We admit Certificate students in both Fall and Spring terms. The deadlines for Â Certificate applications is July 1 (for Fall) and November 15 (for Spring).
Â 
We offer a few graduate assistantships each year to MA students; these include a tuition waiver and a small stipend ($7200) across the year in exchange for working 8 hours/week with a professor. We do not offer Graduate Assistantships to Certificate students.Â 
Â 
The application is comprised of:Â a brief statement of interestÂ (wherein applicants describe why they want to pursue a certificate or MA in Gerontology, their passion for the field, and/or their research interests), three letters of reference, and transcripts.Â We do not require theÂ GRE.Â You may begin your application here.Â 
Â 
Our 18-credit Certificate program offers a specialized credential in Gerontology for professionals or graduate students in other fields.Â ThisÂ program typically takes one year to complete.Â Â 
Â 
Our 9-credit Certificate in Leadership and Aging is designed for people who are already working in the field in some way, who would like to gain knowledge in the field as well as a credential.
Â 
AllÂ credits earned in our Certificate programs may be applied toÂ ourÂ MA degree.
Â 
Interested studentsÂ are welcome toÂ contact me directlyÂ with questions about the programs or the application process: Â wsimonds@gsu.edu.

AON Corporation 
Opportunity for Sophomores only
The Sophomore Actuarial Mentor Program connects students with experienced professionals in the field to provide guidance, career insights, and networking opportunities. Itâ€™s designed to help students explore the actuarial profession, understand some of the paths to becoming an actuary, and build meaningful connections early in their academic journey. We also give participants that are engaged and interested an opportunity to apply and interview for roles early for our Summer 2026 actuarial opportunities.
Â 
We work to pair students with mentors in the office location/line of work that they are most interested in exploring for future opportunities.
Â 
The program is currently accepting applications, and we would love to reach as many students as possible who may be interested in this program!
Â 
Here are the key details:
Â 
	â€¢	Eligibility: Open to sophomores (December 2026 â€“ June 2027 grads) with a 3.0 GPA interested in exploring or pursuing actuarial science
	â€¢	Format: Fully Virtual program that runs February-May with a commitment of ~1 hr/week. We do our best to work around their schedules and record group sessions when possible!
	â€¢	How to apply: Early Careers: Sophomore Actuarial Mentorship Program in Multiple Locations | Aon Corporation

subject: SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
Â 
Emory's Center for AI Learning is now accepting applications to participate in the Spring 2025 AI. Data Lab program!
Â 
AI.DataÂ Lab is a 10 week, data micro-consulting project hosted by the Center for AI Learning where students will work in teams to solve real-world problems with data. Each team will gain exposure to the world of professional data analytics by tackling issues presented by companies in the Atlanta area and developing data-driven solutions for them.Â 
For this iteration, students will have the opportunity to work with the following organizations:
	â€¢	TechBridge (TB): TB is a non-profit whose mission is to alleviate generational poverty by equipping other non-profits with enterprise-grade software and technology. Students will investigate and leverage over 18+ years of transactional national data to improve the foundational algorithm for TB's flagship software addressing hunger relief.
	â€¢	Sustainability Office (SO): The Emory Sustainability Office is interested in invoking sustainability into AI practices. This project will task students to creatively brainstorm how to approach either better understanding energy usage of AI, how to inform users of their individual AI tool behaviors' impact on energy, and/or how Emory could measure and report on sustainable AI practices.
	â€¢	Emory Department of Chemistry (C): Over the last 10 years, the Department of Chemistry has revamped its curriculum to improve the experience of Chemistry majors. After collecting a large amount of evaluation and survey data, this AI.DataÂ Lab project will analyze the success of the curriculum overhaul and pitch how the department can continue to improve.Â 
	â€¢	InvestAtlanta (IA): IA is a local government authority for Atlanta focused on the economic and equitable improvement of the city. Students will conduct a sentiment analysis of governmental-adjacent agencies, like InvestAtlanta, to understand public perception of agencies that work in this industry.
Students with all kinds of experience levels are encouraged to apply. However, selected students will be expected to be able to work with Python in order to perform analysis. Teams will be created in such a way to induce the greatest experiential diversity within each team as to allow those with less experience to learn from students with more background in programming. Undergraduate students are eligible to receive 1 credit hour in INTERN496R to achieve their Experience & Application (XA) credit for their participation.
All participants in the AI.DataÂ Lab program will be expected to attend weekly meetings on Thursdays from 6:00 - 7:30 in White Hall. These meetings are meant to provide students with a common time and location to work with their teams.Â  Topics can range from soft skills, such as data storytelling, to hard skills like string processing. Therefore, students applying must have this block of time free in their weekly schedule --Â at least two-thirds of these weekly meetings must be attended to earn a Pass/Satisfactory grade, and/or to be credited in final deliverables. If this time does not work for you, AI.DataÂ Lab will be offered in subsequent semesters and you are encouraged to apply for later iterations.
Â 
Applications are due by 5:00 p.m. on Tuesday, January 21.Â The first weekly meeting will take place at 6:00PM on January 30th. If you have any questions, please reach out to tottoli@emory.edu.
Â 
The application can be found here: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=nPsE4KSwT0K80DImBtXfONoMV0zVh_FDuG1Bf6CV029UNzhRNFUwMUM2SUxOSzhYSDBBVDYxSk9OUC4u.
Â 
Â 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University

GRADUATING SENIORS !This posting closes on Jan 6th):https://www.usajobs.gov/job/826182600
Â 
The National Endowment for the Humanities' Office of Data and Evaluation (ODE) seeks an analyst to respond to internal data/analysis requests. They will also support occasional other office needs, including empowering agency staff with dashboards to help with decision-making and supporting the development of ODE's grant programs.
Â 
The role is based in Washington, DC with aÂ salary range of $85k-$157k. Current agency policy allows remote work, but applicants should not apply unless they are prepared to relocate to DC if policies change.
Â 
Federal job applications pass through HR staff before they reach the hiring manager. Applicants must specifically address how their backgrounds match the required qualifications in their resume / cover letter, or their materials may not reach the final hiring panel.Â 
Â 
Anyone with experience in the humanities and data analysis is encouraged to apply.Â

Do you have an early-stage startup that you want to rapidly move forward? Apply now to the Techstars Emory Founder Catalyst-Â (Due Jan 17, 2025). This spring, the Startup Launch Accelerator is evolving into The Techstars Emory Founder Catalyst.
The Techstars Emory Founder Catalyst is a 10-week pre-accelerator program providing early-stage for-profit entrepreneurs with invaluable startup education and mentorship from one of the top accelerators in the world.
The Techstars Emory Founder Catalyst might be right for you if you have:Domain expertiseYou possess deep understanding or unique insight into the challenge your startup is addressing.A clear problem to solveYou have identified a well-defined customer need and have a lead on the solution.Raised less than $1MFounders of early- or idea-stage companies raised less than $1M will receive the most benefit from the program structure and activities.
A collaborative spiritMaximizing the program experience demands excellent communication skills for collaboration with your cohort, mentors, and program leaders.

OPPORTUNITY

Â 
TEDxEmory will host its main conferenceÂ this year on February 22nd, 2025.Â 
Â 
Our conference brings leaders, experts, and professionals from all over the world to give TED talks at Emory. Currently, we have an executive at Georgia Public Broadcasting, a Paralympic gold medalist, and a high-profile Neurosurgeon/InfluencerÂ in the lineup.Â 
Â 
In addition to 10 professional speakers, the conference features TWO EMORY STUDENT SPEAKERSÂ from undergraduate and graduate schools.Â 
Â 
The talks are professionally recorded and posted on the official TED YouTube website. Our talks have millions of views and hundreds of people attend our conference! This is a wonderful opportunity to network with professionals from around the country and to share ideas with a wider audience.
Â 
This event encourages the exchange of professionally workshopped and developed ideas between students, faculty, and professionals. This is a unique opportunity for students from your department to share their knowledge, passion, and research in their fields.Â 
Â 
If you know of any students in your network who may have valuable insights to share, we would greatly appreciate it if you could help us spread the word and encourage them to apply by sharing the message above.
Â 
Link to the application form: https://forms.gle/VEs7dDbL2TFhRJjy6
Check out some of our past TEDxEmory Conferences: https://www.tedxemory.org/
Â 
Â Thank you for your time and consideration in supporting TEDxEmory
Â 
If you have any questions, please reach out to isabella.aguado@emory.edu
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
OPPORTUNITY
Â 
Â 
The Marcus Autism Center, in conjunction with the Emory University School of Medicine and Children's Healthcare of Atlanta, is offering five fellowships: the Cohen Fellowship in Developmental Social Neuroscience, the Simons Fellowship in Computational Neuroscience, the Louise and Brett Samsky Fellowship in Educational Science and Practice, the Sally Provence Fellowship in Clinical Research, and the ACCESS Fellowship in Implementation Science. 
Students who will receive a bachelor's degree by June 2025 will be eligible for the positions. The fellowships will commence in July 2025, and they are 2 years in duration. Students can find further details here. 
Attached, please find a brochure describing the fellowships. Please feel free to print the brochure and post it in your department. I ask that you let us know that you have received this e-mail and that you forward it, along with the associated brochure, to students in the Department of Quantitative Theory and Methods. 
The Cohen Fellowship in Developmental Social Neuroscience will involve cutting-edge social neuroscience and/or neuroimaging research in infants, toddlers and adolescents. Fellows will work to further the understanding of autism through eye-tracking research, guiding a project from the point of data collection to publication of results. 
The Simons Fellowship in Computational Neuroscience will involve integrating computational strategies with clinical research goals. Fellows will develop methods for the analysis of visual scanning and eye-tracking data, computational models of visual salience, and data visualization techniques, all with the aim of advancing the understanding of autism and efforts at early diagnosis. 
The Louise and Brett Samsky Fellowship in Educational Science and Practice will involve research in educational innovations in autism. Fellows will learn about classroom-based interventions to increase social emotional engagement and inclusion, gaining experiences with observational research methods, practical experience through direct classroom responsibilities, cutting edge intervention research, and implementation science approaches. 
The Sally Provence Fellowship in Clinical Research will select fellows for a two-year training in clinical assessment measures and research methodologies to better understand ASD and related disabilities. 
The ACCESS Fellowship in Implementation Science will select fellows for a two-year training in research focused on community engagement participatory methods, translating evidence-based treatments for autism into community settings, as well as the processes and partnerships that support these efforts. 
Thank you for your help! We look forward to hearing from you. 
Sincerely, Marcus Predoctoral Fellowship Committee 

Marcus Autism Center, Children's Healthcare of Atlanta, & Emory University School of Medicine Phone: 404-785-9554 Email: marcus.predoc-fellowships@emory.edu

Â 
The MARC Undergraduate Scholars Program is now accepting applications for our 2025-2026 cohort!
Â 
In short, the Maximizing Student Access to Research Careers (MARC) Undergraduate Scholars Program is a NIH-funded, two-year research and academic program for undergraduate scholars in STEM research. The program focuses on multi-level mentoring, research integrity, and career preparation to nurture students to become successful graduates from high-caliber Ph.D. programs in the biomedical and behavioral sciences fields. Moreover, selected MARC Scholars receive up to $16,000 in tuition, a $14,340 stipend, and a $1000 travel award to attend scientific meetings annually!Â 
Â 
The deadline for the MARC Undergraduate Scholar Application and required Faculty Recommendation Questionnaire, which will automatically be sent directly to the recommender, is Friday, December 20th, 2024, at 11:59 pm.Â Students can access the MARC Undergraduate Scholar Application via College Connect. After signing onto College Connect with an Emory NetID, students should click the Application Center to find the MARC Undergraduate Scholar Application under the Undergraduate Research Programs category.
Â 
If you have any questions, feel free to contact the Associate Director, Kristen Walden, via email (kawalde@emory.edu).
Â 
Flyer and application attached
Â 
Â 
Submitted by Kristen A. Walden, PhD
Â 
Â 
Â 

Â 
The University of Bath UK is seeking a highly motivated PhD student with career goals in medical statistics.Â 
Â 
Successful applicant will be working on a fully funded project, titledÂ Incorporating Covariate Information to Design and Analyse Precision Medicine Clinical Trials, supervised by Dr Haiyan Zheng.
An overview of the project can be found athttps://www.findaphd.com/phds/project/?p176735Industrial partner: This project will benefit from collaboration with Dr Michael Grayling (Senior Principal Statistician, Johnson & Johnson), a statistical expert with extensive experience in adaptive designs for clinical trials. Dr Grayling will join the supervision meetings on a regular basis and will in particular provide industry-linked expertise on the practicality of statistical methods developed from this project.Â Â 
Project keywords: Bayesian statistics, borrowing of information, covariate, experimental design, mixture model, subgroupClosing date: 12 January 2025Funding note: This project is directly funded by the University of Bath for entry in September 2025, and the studentship is tenable for 3 years. Funding covers tuition fees,Â a stipend (Â£19,237 p/a in 2024/5) and access to a Â£1,000 training support budget.Non-UK applicants must meet the programmeâ€™s English language requirement by the application deadline.
Informal enquiries about this post or project may be made to Dr Haiyan Zheng: hz2075 (at) bath (dot) ac (dot) uk
Â 
Â 
Submitted by Sandra Ruhlman Smith

Â 

A four year fully funded PhD studentship is available at Warwick Medical School, University of Warwick, as part of the MRC Doctoral Training Partnership.Â 
Â 
The program involves a one-year MSc in Interdisciplinary Biomedical Research, followed by a three-year PhD project co-supervised by Professor Nigel Stallard (Warwick Clinical Trials Unit) and Dr Cornelia Ursula Kunz (Global Statistics and Data Science Unit, Boehringer Ingelheim, Germany) focussing on Innovative statistical methods for dose-finding in clinical drug development. Â The student will spend at least 3 months at the Boehringer Ingelheim site in Biberach an der Riss (Germany).
Â 
For further details, please see
https://www.findaphd.com/phds/project/innovative-statistical-methods-for-dose-finding-in-clinical-drug-development/?p175825
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
Omicron Delta Kappa, the National Leadership Honor Society, recognizes and encourages superior leadership and exemplary character. Founded in 1914, Oâˆ†K encourages collaboration among members across five pillars of leadership: academics and research, athletics, service to campus and community, communications, and creative and performing arts.
Â 
The Emory University chapter of Omicron Delta Kappa was founded in 1925 and strives to foster excellence in service, research, academics, athletics, and the performing arts. Applications are open to current juniors, seniors, and graduate students, and requirements include a minimum 3.6 GPA and a significant demonstration of leadership on campus.
Â 
Applicants should start at the Apply for Membership page, which provides instructions for 1) creating an account and 2) applying for membership using that account.
Â 
Please complete the following items to complete your application for Emory Universityâ€™s chapter of ODK:Â 
Â 
National ODK Application:Â 
https://odk.org/members/apply-for-membership/
Â 
Emory University ODK Application:Â 
https://forms.gle/8RMJJmudisNoT4in8
Â 
Both application components are due on November 15th, 2024. Your application will not be considered if both elements are not completed!!Â

Delta Phi Lambda, an Asian-interest sorority is hosting a career development event designed to support women of color! 
Â 
Come join this empowering resource discovery event on November 7th from 6-8pm in Harland Cinema.Â 
At the event students can:
* Get free professional headshots (first 50 RSVPs)
* Receive resume, LinkedIn, and interview tips from women leaders
* Network with professional women in healthcare, STEM, business, academia, and nonprofits
* Gain insider advice for succeeding as a woman of color

Â 
COPSS-NISS Leadership Webinar: Leadership in Linking Statistical Theory and Scientific Inquiry
Date& Time: Tuesday, October 29, 2024 - 12:00pmÂ to 1:00pm ET
Event Page: https://www.niss.org/events/copss-niss-leadership-webinar-leadership-linking-statistical-theory-and-scientific-inquiry
Zoom Registration Link:Â us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/...
Â 
Overview:Â Join us for an insightful webinar exploring the role of leadership in bridging statistical theory with scientific inquiry. This event, co-hosted by COPSS and NISS, brings together distinguished leaders in statistics and data science to discuss the critical intersections of theory, research, and practice. Attendees will gain valuable perspectives on how statistical methodologies drive innovation and shape scientific progress across various disciplines. This is a must-attend event for statisticians, researchers, and professionals looking to enhance their leadership and impact in the field.
Speakers
Michael R. Kosorok, PhD, W.R. Kenan, Jr. Distinguished Professor of Biostatistics, Professor of Statistics and Operations Research, and Director of the Gillings School Center for AI and Public Health, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
Daniela Witten,Â Professor of Statistics and Biostatistics at University of Washington, and the Dorothy Gilford Endowed Chair in Mathematical Statistics.
Moderator
Anru Zhang, Professor, Departments of Biostatistics & Bioinformatics and Computer Science & Departments of Statistical Science, Electrical & Computer Engineering, and Mathematics, Duke University.
Register on Zoom Here!
Â 
Â 
About the COPSS-NISS Leadership Webinar Series
COPSS (Committee of the Presidents of Statistical Societies) and NISS have come together to organize and host a new webinar series focusing on leadership in statistics and data science. Plan to attend these webinars every month during the academic year!Â Visit the COPSS-NISS Leadership Series PageÂ for previous webinars.
The COPSS-NISS Leadership Webinar Series is co-organized by the Committee of the PresidentsÂ of Statistical Societies (COPSS) Emerging Leaders in StatisticsÂ and the National Institute ofÂ Statistical Sciences (NISS). The purpose of the webinar series is to promote leadership skills forÂ members of the statistical societies at any stage in their careers. The series features conversations with leaders throughout the discipline, including leaders from major academic and government institutions, and companies. Invited speakers share their leadership stories and answer questions about their experiences. Each webinar is moderated by a member of the COPSS Emerging Leaders in Statistics program.

subject: Opportunity today
content:
ANNOUNCEMENT
Â 
The National Consortium for Data Science (NCDS) is pleased to announce the next Foundations of AI course. AI for Non-Coders, taught by Amy Hemmeter, will take place on Thursday, September 26 at 1 PM ET.Foundations of AI will fulfill the NCDS mission to connect diverse communities of data science experts to support a 21st century data-driven economy by creating a data-literate workforce and bridging the gap between data scientists in the public and private sectors requires educational and upskilling opportunities. A limited number of full scholarship opportunities will be available on a case-by-case basis. Please contact Amanda Miller for more information.
Â 
We would greatly appreciate any help you could provide to promote this event to staff, students, faculty, and community members who may be interested. 
Â 
Iâ€™ve attached graphics and have included additional information below. Please let me know if you have any questions, and thank you in advance for your review.
Â 
Â 
Foundations of AI: AI for Non-Coders | September 26 at 1 PM ET
Ever say to yourself: what even is an LLM? How do I get from chatting with ChatGPT to talking about larger AI products? How do I answer these nonstop questions from colleagues, customers, leadership and more in this new landscape? Do you find yourself needing expertise on AI that, quite frankly, you didnâ€™t sign up for? This course is designed to meet the needs of people who are not necessarily well-versed in math and science but who know that they need to know the basics about AI in this changing landscape. Youâ€™ll learn about what AI can accomplish, the intuitions behind how it works (no math or coding necessary!), and opportunities and risks. Youâ€™ll come away feeling confident that you know not only what an LLM actually is, but understand all the jargon people use to talk about it. Scholarships are available on a case-by-case basis.
Â 
Those interested in the event can register directly at this link: https://bit.ly/AI_NonCoders_NCDS.Â

subject: OPPORTUNITTY ANNOUNCEMENTS- WEEK OF 9/16/2024
content:
OPPORTUNITY ANNOUNCEMENTS THIS WEEK
Â 
Â 
The Editorial Board at Emory needs you!
Â 
The Editorial Board is a diverse group of opinion journalists who articulate the Wheelâ€™s opinion on issues important to the Emory community. Being a part of this team provides students with or without a background in journalism a fantastic opportunity to think critically about a wide variety of current events and work collaboratively to draft articles about them. Our past work (see hereÂ for examples) has won regional and national awards from the Society of Professional Journalists and administrators regularly read our coverage.
Â 
Each week, we meet twice (Wednesdays and Sundays)â€”once to brainstorm article topics and debate our collective position on them and once to group-edit the articles that arise from those discussionsâ€”and publish 1-2 articles. If you are interested, our application (this Microsoft Form) is due at 11:59pm on September 18.
Â 
If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to me at marc.goedemans@emory.edu Thank you very much for your time and consideration. We look forward to hearing from you soon!
Â 
Â 
Â 
OPPORTUNITY FOR SCHOLOARSHIP FOR JUNIORS
Â 
The National Scholarships and Fellowships Program is excited to announce an upcoming Beinecke Info Session on Wednesday, September 18thÂ from 11:30am-12:30pm in Tarbutton 120AÂ hosted by Dr. Matthew Loar, Director of the Beinecke Scholarship Program.Â 
The Beinecke Scholarship provides $30,000 throughout graduate school and an additional $5,000 stipend upon being selected as a recipient. Emory's most recent recipient of this highly competitive award was sociology majorÂ  Courtney Fitzgerald '25C, who was selected this summer as one of just 20 Beinecke Scholars across the U.S.Â 
To be eligible for this opportunity, students must be: Â 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Juniors
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Planning to pursue a masterâ€™s or Doctoral program in the Arts, Humanities or Social Sciences
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  U.S. Citizens or U.S. National
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Eligible for need-based financial aid (with a preference for Pell Grant recipients)
For more info about this award, including more recent recipients, Â visit our website.Â  Weâ€™re eager to spread the word to as many eligible and interested students as possible and would greatly appreciate it if you could share this message.
If there are any questions or additional information required, do not hesitate to reach out to us directly at ec.nationalawards@emory.eduÂ .
Â 
Â 
MBA PROGRAM INFORMATION
Â 

MIT Sloan will be joining other top business schools in-person at Atlantaâ€™s Insight into Deferred Enrollment Programs on Wednesday, September 18, 2024. We hope to connect with high-potential students from Emory University at this event. 
Please share this email with those in your student communities who may be interested. You can also download our MBA EarlyÂ fact sheet to share with students and learn more about our deferred admissions offering on our website. 
TheÂ event will feature a moderated conversation with admissions representatives as well as a chance to network with each participating university.
Â 
Â 
The 2024 International Education Week Essay Contest
Â For those of you who are not yet aware, staff from ISSS, GSI and other offices across Emory have been organizing events and activities to promote International Education Week (IEW) at Emory the week of November 18th. You can find details about what is scheduled so far here, and this site will be updated as events are added. We hope that you will attend events of interest and promote them as well.
Â 
As part of IEW, we are excited to share that the 2024 International Education Week Essay Contest is now open for submissions! The contest, which runs until Sunday, October 6th at 11:59pm EST,Â encourages all currently enrolled Emory students to submit a 500-750 word essay on the impact global experiences have made on their time at Emory, whether in Atlanta or elsewhere in the world.Â 
Â 
There will be two first place prizes of $500 for undergraduate and graduate essays respectively, and two additional runner-up prizes ofÂ $250 for each category. All rules and guidelines are accessible on the website, where students can also access the form to submit their essay. Winners and runners-up will be invited to read their essays during an event during International Education Week.
Â 
Please find attached the official contest flyer, which we encourage you to share with your networks and the wider Emory community.
Â 
Â

subject: Special Announcement
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
From Alexander Tolbert 
QTM Department faculty
Â 
Â 
I'm excited to announce the launch of the Tolbert-Black Digital Research Lab (BDRL-ATL) at Emory University, focused on preserving and advancing Black history, philosophy, theology, culture, and art in Atlanta through digital humanities and AI technologies.
Â 
The Lab is building a comprehensive digital archive of Black intellectual, cultural, and artistic contributions in Atlanta, including texts, oral histories, visual art, literature, and music. We support interdisciplinary research that explores the impact of Black thought on social justice movements and contemporary debates, ensuring that cultural expressions are accessible for future scholarship and public engagement.
Â 
We offer training programs for Black students from the Atlanta metro area and HBCUs, equipping them with skills in coding, digital humanities, AI, and LLMs, preparing them for leadership in academia, technology, and public history.
Â 
A key focus of our work is extracting "thick data" from archival research and ethnographic studies to inform the design of AI systems and the development of Black-centered datasets and ethical AI frameworks.
Â 
Our Risk-Informed Design Pipeline identifies and addresses potential harms in AI development, ensuring that AI models are accurate and socially responsible. We also develop and curate datasets that reflect Black experiences, contributing to the creation of fair and robust AI models.
Â 
Signature projects include the Atlanta Black Philosophy, Theology, and Art Archive, the Thick Data Collection Initiative, Black-Centered Algorithmic Fairness, and Mapping Black Atlanta, an interactive digital map of significant sites in the cityâ€™s Black history.
Â 
Please share this with any interested students. They can learn more about the Lab and opportunities by visiting our website. https://sites.google.com/view/alextolbertlab/aboutâ€
Â 
Â 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University

(she/her/hers)

subject: GREAT INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITY
content:
GREAT INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITY
Â 
Â 
Â 
Science for Georgia is looking for 1-3 interns for the Fall 2024 semester.
Students will gain in-depth understanding of the Science for Georgia Data Analytics Program by contributing to a specific data-for-good story.Â  The data analysis program is centered on using existing environmental and social data to produce contextualized data stories about the physical, economic and environmental health of Georgia communities.Â 
Â 
Gain hands-on experience in storytelling with data, utilizing real world â€œmessyâ€ data, and being part of a project and data management process.Â 
Â 
The goal is for the intern to become a â€œProject Managerâ€ of a data team during a Spring QTM Capstone project class. The product of the QTM Capstone will be a contextualized public-facing data story.
	â€¢	Weekly Hours: 10-20
Â 
	â€¢	Location: 100% remote. Sci4Ga has co-working space in Atlanta and interns are welcome to join us there.
Â 
	â€¢	Expected Skills:
	â—¦	Ability to work in Excel, Python and/or R
	â—¦	Basic data analysis techniques
	â—¦	Ability to manage time in a fast-paced environment
	â—¦	Ability to independently carry out research tasks
	â—¦	Some previous experience working with geospatial data and GIS software like ArcGIS or GeoPandas or a strong willingness to learn!
Â 
A full description of the role and expectations can be seen at bit.ly/3AL5lGC
This internship will be for class credit and follow the fall semester calendar.Â  Students who are selected for this internship will be enrolled in QTM 496R for 3 credit hours.
Â 
Interested students can complete the application at https://forms.office.com/r/FZe9VrU3BT.
We will begin reviewing applications at 5:00 PM on September 5th.

Course title: Ethical Emerging TechnologiesDescription:Â This course explores the ethical implications and governance challenges of emerging technologies such as AI, autonomous vehicles, autonomous weapons, digital medicine, blockchain, sustainability and the environment, and IoT. Students will explore key pillars of ethical tech development, including explainability, fairness, bias and privacy, while also learning about the economic impact of emerging technologiesÂ such as AI.

subject: New Class Announcement
content:
NEW CLASS ANNOUNCEMENT
Â 
Topics in Quantitative Science: Unlocking the Future with AI
Includes topics related to statistical computing.
Â 
QTM 285Â  - Section 2, Â Class # 6295
Credit Hours:Â 3
Â 
Schedule and Location: Â Â W 4pm-7pmÂ in ONLINE
Instruction Method:Â Distance Learning
Â 
Instructor:Â  Dr. Richard Pocklington 
Â 
Prompting and Meta Prompting: Unlocking the Future with AI -
Dive into the rapidly evolving field of AI to learn how to use the transformative techniques of prompting and meta prompting in large language models (LLMs). Gain a solid foundation in AI and LLMs fundamentals to broaden your ability to craft effective prompts to elicit desired outputs. Through hands-on projects and case studies, learn to design, optimize, and evaluate prompts for various applications (such as structured text generation and sentiment analysis). Explore advanced topics like Chain of Thought, Graph of Thought, and Tree of Thought to leverage LLMs for complex tasks. Ethical implications of LLMs will also be explored. Engage with cutting-edge research, industry experts, and real-world datasets while developing practical skills in AI frameworks and tools. By course end, be equipped to apply prompting and meta prompting across domains, making significant contributions to your chosen application area with state-of-the-art LLM applications.
To successfully complete this course, students should have completed QTM 100 Intro to Stat Inference and QTM 150 Introduction to Statistical Computing I, or equivalent coursework.
Â 
Best,

subject: New Class Announcement for fall 2024
content:
NEW CLASS ANNOUNCEMENT FOR FALL 2024
Â 
Intensive version of QTM 220 Regression Analysis and will count for QTM 220 requirement
It is particularly useful for AMS majors and other students with a strong math background
Â 
Â 
QTM 285-1 Prediction, Inference, & Causality 
A Rigorous Introduction to Prediction, Inference, and Causality
Â 
MW 4pm-5:15pm Â room 230 - New Psyc Bldg (36 Eagle Row)
F 2:30pm-3:20pm Â room 220 - New Psyc Bldg (36 Eagle Row)
Â 
Instructor:Â  Dr. David Hirshberg
Â 
This class will be accepted in place of QTM 220 and there is substantial overlap in content between the two. However, there will be a greater emphasis on the precision with which we move from stories and intuition to formal mathematical reasoning--and back--in this course. Data visualization, including sketching by hand and plotting in R, will be emphasized as a tool for making this connection.
Â 
A modern, mathematically rigorous introduction to statistical modeling and data-driven decision-making that provides a foundation for upper-level classes in the department. We will focus on prediction---using data we have to tell us something about data we don't, statistical inference---characterizing the uncertainty we have about the accuracy of these predictions, and causal inference---understanding what the relationships we see in the data tell us about the impact of actions we might take. While the class will emphasize the intuitive and mathematical foundations of these concepts, we will also cover the implementation of these techniques in applications using the statistical programming language R.
Â 
To succeed in this course, students should have the same prerequisites as for QTM 220: (QTM 110 or QTM_OX 110) & (QTM 150 or QTM_OX 150) & (QTM 120 or MATH 210 or MATH_OX 210 or MATH_211 or MATH_OX 211) & [QTM 210 or QTM_OX 210 or ECON 220 or ECON_OX 220 or (MATH 361 and MATH 362)] & (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221) or equivalent.
Â 
Â

subject: SUMMER ANNOUNCEMENT
content:
SUMMER ANNOUNCEMENT
Â 
Â 
Invitation to the 2ndÂ AI Summer School, Symposium and Datathon
Â 
Join us for the 2nd Medical Imaging, AI, and Bias Data Symposium happening from August 19 to August 25, 2024, at Emory University. The focus of this symposium is to collaboratively uncover bias, establish collaborations, and provide the opportunity to work with real data, supported by a team that understands the data. Following the success of last yearâ€™s event (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nzXoOyKlOtg), we have observed the need to bridge the communication gap between medical professionals and computer scientists. Therefore, we are dedicating four days to summarizing the common mistakes and pitfalls we have observed, using a case-based approach to learning medical imaging.Â 
Â Â Â 
During these four days, we will offer a case-based learning curriculum that spans from ICU data to Chest X-ray, as well as breast imaging data. We will also be launching EMBED2, a multi-modal breast imaging data, including 3D imaging (tomosynthesis) and MRI imaging, with improved patient outcomes.Â Â 
Â Â 
We hope you can join us. Please register here - https://www.datathon.org
Â

NYC Summer Internship Data Engineering Opportunity: APPLY NOW!
Â 
Role Summary:Â  Jain Global is looking for a motivated Data Engineering Intern to help enhance and integrate its existing data processing and retrieval systems into its main data platform. The intern will be instrumental in refining the data architecture to support advanced search functionalities and efficient data handling. The role is for a 2-3 summer month in-person internship in NYC.Â  See ( attached) job description for details.
Â 
Â 
See attached PDF flyer for more details 
Â 
Â 
Sandra Ruhlman Smith
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
Opportunity
Â 
Seeking Dataverse Developer
Â 
Background
Â 
Recovering the US Hispanic Literary Heritage Program (Recovery) at the University of Houston (UH)Â  
is the largest Hispanic/Latino humanities research program operating in the United States dedicated 
to researching, locating, preserving and making available all literary-historical documents 
produced by Hispanics/Latinos living in the United States from the Colonial Period to 1980.Â 
Â 
Recovery is in the process of creating a customized web-based content repository in Dataverse. 
The repository will hold Recoveryâ€™s vast archives and metadata (file formats include JPG, TIFF, PNG, PDF,
CSV, Excel, and Word). 
Â 
It will allow multi-level access to the assets and their metadata to a range of audiences,
Recovery staff, students, researchers, educators and community members. 
The assets will be made discoverable through fully searchable metadata and indexing on search engines. 
The valuable resource will further scholarship and preservation of Latino historical materials 
(1595 to 1980) through the maintenance, modernization, and consolidation of Recovery archival collections.Â 
Â 
To learn more about Recovery, please visit: https://artepublicopress.com/recovery-program/Â 
Recovery is seeking a developer who can provide customizations and technical support for this effort. This position will implement Dataverse, install software and begin customizations. Customizations to include, but not limited to, developing APIs to accommodate broader search functionalities, bilingual metadata, metadata linking to image files, auto populate features, batch upload features, expanded user roles, and author ownership.Â 
This position is expected to meet with the project team and UH IT to discuss the customizations needed, establish a workflow, and acquire university technology clearance.Â  Additionally, this position will assist in determining the cloud storage service that best suits the projectâ€™s needs.Â 
This position will be remote contract work for 2 years.
Required Qualifications
B.S. Computer Science/Computer Engineering or relevant experience inÂ software development and modification
At least 18 months of programming experienceÂ 
The ideal candidate for this position should possess the following:

What is a QTM Ambassador?
Â 
QTM Ambassadors are an important extension of the QTM department.Â  Â They serve as representatives of QTM with its programming and external partners/advisory board and have the opportunity to develop skills that will serve them in future professional capacities. This includes hostingÂ  events, conducting interviews, communicating with professionals, and engaging the community and student body. Â Â The Ambassador cohort will consist of 15-20Â  currently enrolled Sophomores, Juniors and Seniors who have the following:

	â€¢	Have a 3.0 GPA

	â€¢	Able to meet on Mondays or Fridays at 4:00 PM bi-weekly

Emory Undergraduate Medical Review (EUMR)
We are hosting our annual Emotive Arts Series event this Thursday, April 4th, from 6-8 pm in the Campus Life Pavilion. The Emotive Arts Series seeks to synthesize the arts and medicine, and theÂ topic of this year's Emotive Arts series is Nature vs. Nurture, inspired by the theme of our journal this semester for our 10th anniversary: epigenetics.Â  The event will include a panel featuring various Emory faculty, dance performances, and the presentation of student art and poetry.
We have extended our submission deadline to April 3rdÂ at 11:59PM to allow more students the opportunity to showcase their talents!

See flyer attached for details

MESSAGE FROM Gabrielle Gershon
Â 
My name is Gabby, and I am a medical student currently working on a research project focused on coronary artery calcium phenotypes and their implications for cardiac risk assessment. We are seeking an undergraduate student with skills in data analyticsÂ to join our team and help analyze trends in our patient database. ğŸ˜Š
Â 
The project aims to evaluate coronary artery calcium phenotypes in a diverse patient population, with the ultimate goal of creating a fair and unbiased method for assessing the risk of adverse cardiac events such as strokes and heart attacks based on coronary artery calcium levels. As a member of our team, you will have the opportunity to work with real-world patient data and contribute to groundbreaking research in the field of cardiology.
Â 
This position offers the opportunity to earn research for credit, providing valuable experience and enhancing your resume. If you are interested in joining our team, please send your resume to me at gabrielle.gershon@emory.edu
Â 
Thank you for considering this opportunity. I look forward to potentially working together and discussing the project in more detail.

MESSAGE FROM MADELINE PROCTOR

A student-run publication focused on topics at the forefront of science and medicine. We are holding the 2024 Emotive Arts Series, an annual event hosted by EUMR that synthesizes medicine and the arts, and are calling all poets, writers, and artists to consider contributing their work to be showcased at our event! The theme of this spring's journal, in honor of our 10th year anniversary, is epigenetics, and this event will similarly evaluate the effect of nature and nurture on one's health. The event will feature artists, poets, performers, and a panel with experts from throughout Emory. The event will take place on Thursday, April 4th from 6-8 pm in the Campus Life Pavilion and all submissions will be due by March 31. We were hoping you can share thisÂ GoogleÂ FormÂ with your departmentÂ listserv to spread the word. In it there is information about the submission deadline and how we plan to collaborate with those interested to show off their work.

The New England Statistical Society (NESS - https://nestat.org) is happy to share theÂ NESS NextGen scholarships for underrepresented minorities in statistics and data science. The purpose of these scholarships is to advance the representation of underrepresented groups in statistics and data science by supporting graduating high school seniors and first/second-year undergraduate students who are interested in pursuing a career in statistics and/or data science.Â 
Â 
Eligibility:Â 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Graduating high school senior or first/second-year undergraduate studentÂ 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Black, Indigenous or Person of Color (BIPOC)Â 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Will be enrolled in a U.S. college or university for the upcoming 2024-2025 academic year.Â 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Shows aÂ genuineÂ interest in statistics and data science through coursework, extracurricular activities, and/or future goalsÂ 
A priority will be given for students who are eligible for a Federal Pell Grant Program (for more information, please see this information pageÂ from the U.S. Department of Education).Â 
Deadline:Â April 15, 2024Â 
Amount:Â at least $1,000Â 
Applications are currently open, apply here: https://nextgenscholarship.nestat.org/Â 
Â 
Submitted by Sandra Ruhlman Smith

Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 

Â 
The London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine has a PhD program opportunity open for applications on the topic of improving the efficiency of randomised trials through prognostic covariates and Bayesian borrowing methods.
Â 
The details of the PhD scheme can be found here: https://ubel-dtp.ac.uk/co-fundedandcollaborative/
Â 
and the specifics of the project here: https://ubel-dtp.ac.uk/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/Alex-Lewin-with-AstraZeneca.pdf
Â

subject: REMINDER - Special Announcement
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT 
Â 
2024 Summer AI XPERIENCE
Â Â Â Â Â (applications are now open)
Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â See below and attached flyer
Â 
Â 
Emory University's Center for AI Learning and QTM department are excited to solicit applications from students for the 2024 Summer AI Xperience. In this program, students will work in teams of 5 to complete one of many different data science consulting projects. Each of these projects will contain a mixture of programming and data analysis tasks that will require developing a strong substantive knowledge surrounding the problem.
Â 
To be selected, students need to:
	â€¢	Have been enrolled in classes at Emory in the Spring 2024 semester and be enrolled at Emory in the Fall 2024 semester.
	â€¢	Be in residence in Atlanta, GA between July 1 and August 15.
	â€¢	Attend 3 or 4 in-person team meetings per week.
	â€¢	Be able to commit roughly 20 hours per week to the project over the 6 week period.
	â€¢	Have knowledge of common statistical analysis and machine learning methods
	â€¢	Have experience programming in R and/or Python:
	â—¦	Ability to load in and manipulate large data sets
	â—¦	Ability to clean potentially messy data into workable formats
	â—¦	Knowledge of common programming control structuresÂ 
	â—¦	Ability to write and debug original functions
	â—¦	Ability to implement common statistical analysis and machine learning methods
	â—¦	Ability to read documentation about new methods and implement them
Â 
Review of applications will begin on March 7, 2024.Â  However, all applications will be considered if submitted prior to 5:00 PM on March 19, 2024.Â  Prior to final selection, some students may be asked to do a short in-person interview.Â  All students will be informed of the status of their application no later than March 21, 2024.
Â 
Students who are admitted to this program will have the option to participate in exchange for credit. For example, QTM majors and minors who participate may choose to count this experience as 3 credit hours ofÂ QTM 498R. QTM 498R mayÂ count as a 300+ level elective towards your QTM degree (or as an experiential elective for those on the Data Science track).Â  Note that most QTM majors/minors may only count one semester of QTM 498R or QTM 495A/495BW towards their degree. We will work with your department's leadership to confirm what course codes are applicable for your experience.
Â 
Students who choose to take advantage of any of these options will be required to pay the associated tuition. You can notate if you would like to enroll in 3 or 6 credit hours, which would impact whether financial aid could be applied. Unfortunately, our funding model does not allow us to cover this tuition, so paying this will be your responsibility. The tuition cost and information about need-based financial aid can be found at https://oue.college.emory.edu/advising/summer-school/tuition-financial-aid.html.
Â 
Students will be asked in this survey whether they are interested in counting this program towards an elective course requirement, as opposed to treating this experience as an internship without credit. Students will also be asked about their potential financial plan in order to enroll in the program in this survey.
Â 
The application for this program can be found here.Â  If the hyperlink is not working, copy and paste the following link in your browser: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=nPsE4KSwT0K80DImBtXfOK9f-T_naQBMvN-s-998aalUN0NIR0Q4NzJYNVNXUVlHSUZTUUhaSEI0Wi4u
Â 
If there are any questions, please do not hesitate to reach out to Dr. Kevin McAlister (kevin.mcalister@emory.edu). Â To schedule office hours or advising appointments with Dr. McAlister, please use this booking page.
Â 
Â 
Â 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University
Email: shanna9@emory.edu | 470-620-7981
(she/her/hers)

Â 
Message from
Margaret Corcoran RecruitmentÂ  DirectorÂ  with Green Corps. 
Field School for Environmental Organizing 
Â 
We are looking for people who are concerned by the state of the environment and who want to do something about it. Our yearlong program has prepared recent college graduates for 30 years to launch a career in environmental Â organizing and advocacy by providing hands-on experience running campaigns with groups like the Wilderness Society, Endangered Species Coalition, Mighty Earth and more. We then connect our graduates to jobs in the environmental and social change movement.
Â 
Green Corps Organizer Program - The Field School for Environmental Organizing
Green Corps is looking for college graduates who are ready to take on the biggest environmental challenges of our day.
Learn more and apply on our website!
Â 
The planet needs all the help it can get. To win now and build a strong foundation for lasting progress, we need people who know how to organize: to run organizations and campaigns that will inspire the support and action we need to save our environment. Our program starts with intensive classroom training. You learn about issues and campaigns, organizing theory and principles, and skills from recruiting volunteers to staging a media event. Then, you move to a more hands-on experience. You make a difference on important campaigns to transition our country to clean energy, protect wildlife, and more. For example, Lauren Karpinski, an organizer from the Green Corps Class of 2019, brought together a coalition of 40 groups that helped win a landmark solar energy bill in Arkansas.
Â 
Weâ€™re accepting the top 20 candidates for our 2024-2025 program. Graduates will join our more than 400 alumni who are leading environmental campaigns and organizations across the country. If youâ€™re passionate about the environment and ready to learn and practice the craft of organizing after graduation, apply today!
Â 
Not a graduating senior? Add your name to our list to receive updates about Green Corps including summer internships and jobs in the environmental and broader social change field!
Â 
Green Corpsâ€™ year-long program begins in August 2024 with introductory classroom training, and continues with field placements in multiple locations across the U.S. Candidates must be willing to relocate. Please contact Margaret Corcoran at margaret@greencorps.org with additional questions.
Â 
Green Corps is part of The Public Interest Network, which operates and supports organizations committed to a shared vision of a better world and aÂ  strategic approach to social change. Visit publicinterestnetwork.org to learn more. Green Corps is an equal opportunity employer. The target annual compensation for this position is $32,500 (but compensation may range between $32,500 and $39,000 depending on location). Green Corps' benefits package includes medical insurance for employees and dependents, needs-based student loan assistance, commuter benefit program, sick pay (60-72 hours/year depending on location), and 80 hours (2 weeks) of accrued vacation. We also offer short-term positions, an excellent training program, and opportunities for advancement.
Â 
Need more information contact her at (617) 901-6114.
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
Â 
LUNCH & LEARN
Â 
The Emory Center for Digital Scholarship (ECDS) and the Envisioning Baroque Rome digital humanities project invite you for a one-hour round-table Lunch & Learn at noonÂ on Thursday, March 21st in Woodruff Library.
Enjoy a provided lunch while the project team discusses the process of building a 3D model of the city of Rome. Envisioning Baroque Rome began in 2013 with the goal of rebuilding Rome in 1676 according to the map of that year, Nuova piante et alzata della cittÃ  di Roma, and other prints by artist Giovanni Battista Falda. Led by Sarah McPhee, Samuel Candler Dobbs Professor of Art History, the round-table will include ECDS staff Joanna Mundy, Ian Burr, and John Halbert, and artist Nicole Costello Matthews. The team will discuss the research, modeling, texturing, and animation of Baroque Rome, and you will have an opportunity to explore the newest version of the 3D city yourself!
Â 
Learn about the recent research in the project and stroll the streets of Rome with Giovanni Battista Falda.
Â 
We hope that you are able to attend. To RSVP, fill out this formÂ by Monday, March 18th. If you have any questions, please email Joanna Mundy (jcmundy@emory.edu).
Â 
Submitted by Joanna Mundy

Â

Â 
We are seeking talented individuals to join our team andÂ teach EnglishÂ toÂ students around the world! We are looking for tutors with a wide variety of backgrounds and interests from top universities like Emory University.
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  No past teaching experience necessaryÂ but native-level fluency in English is required

subject: SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT FROM DR. KEVIN MCALISTER
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT FROM DR. KEVIN MCALISTER, QTM DIRECTOR OF RESEARCH
Â 
DataThink is a 10-week data micro-consulting project hosted by the QTM Department and Center for Artificial Intelligence Learning where students will work in teams to solve real problems with real data. Each team will learn the context of the problem and develop a data-driven solution. Participants will gain exposure to the world of professional data analytics, working on projects very similar to those that analysts would in their day-to-day work.
Each team of 5 will be working with data from the Better Business Bureau (BBB) to develop insights to understand how to better communicate with businesses (particularly women and black-owned businesses) that do not currently take advantage of the BBB's local business credibility services. Teams will work together to develop an analysis given the research question to be presented as a poster at the DataThink end of year showcase with the best projects (as judged by a panel of data scientists from around the Atlanta community) receiving a best-in-show award and having the teams' names placed on a plaque.Â  Students will also prepare a 3-minute lightning talk to describe their work and conclusions that will be presented to the BBB.Â  The end-of-semester showcase and presentations will be an excellent opportunity to meet with data scientists from around Emory's campus and in the Atlanta community at large.Beginning this semester, all participants in the DataThink program will be expected to attend weekly meetings onÂ Tuesdays from 5:30 - 6:45 in PAIS 290.Â Â The goal of these meetings is to provide students with a common time and place to meet with their teams and discuss how their analysis can progress.Â  Additionally, each weekly meeting will begin with a 20-minute lecture on an important topic in data science that you may or may not have covered in any of your previous classes.Â  Topics will include developing meaningful summary tables, string processing, joining multiple data sources using SQL syntax, effectively designing a project poster, etc.To be allowed at the end of semester event, students must attend at least two-thirds of these weekly meetings.Â  Attendance will be checked via QR code.Â  As such, it is expected that students applying to participate in this program will have this block of time free in their weekly schedule.Â  If this time does not work for you, know that the DataThink program will be offered each semester and you are more than welcome to apply in later semesters.Â Â Students with all kinds of experience levels are encouraged to apply. However, selected students will be expected to be able to work with Python in order to perform analysis.Â  Teams will be created in such a way to induce the greatest experiential diversity within each team as to allow those with less experience to learn from students with more background in programming.Â  Â Selected students will gain experience in the following areas:
	â€¢	Data Storytelling
	â€¢	Insight development for a real client
	â€¢	Professional experience to build oneâ€™s resume
	â€¢	In-demand data technical skills such as Python, SQL, and data visualization tools
	â€¢	Collaboration and teamwork in the data space
To be considered, please have your application in byÂ 5:00 PM on Wednesday, January 31st.Â  The application can be found at https://forms.office.com/r/NaVXn8Q0T8.Â  If the embedded hyperlink does not work, please copy and paste this address into your browser:Â https://forms.office.com/r/NaVXn8Q0T8
Â 
The first weekly meeting will take place atÂ 5:30 on February 6th.Â Â 
Â 
If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to Kevin McAlister at kevin.mcalister@emory.edu.
Â 
Â 
Â 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University
Email: shanna9@emory.edu | 470-620-7981
(she/her/hers)

GREAT OPPORTUNITY
MARC Undergraduate Scholar 2023-2024 cohort
The Maximizing Student Access to Research Careers (MARC) Undergraduate Scholars Program is a National Institutes of Health (NIH)-funded, two-year research and academic program for undergraduate scholars in STEM research (additional information on the MARC grant can be found here).Â The program focuses on multi-level mentoring, research integrity, and career preparation and planning to nurture students to become competitive applicants and successful graduates from high-caliber Ph.D. programs in the biomedical and behavioral sciences fields. Moreover, selected MARC Scholars receive up to $16,000 in tuition, a $14,340 stipend during the academic year, a stipend to support summer research, Â and a $1000 travel award to attend scientific meetings annually!Â 
Â Â 
To be eligible for funding, undergraduate applicants must Â 
(1) be a U.S. citizen or permanent resident from a group underrepresented (UR) in science, Â Â a first-generation college student, or from a disadvantaged background,Â 
(2) be a current second- or third-year student with a preference for second year students who can complete the two-year term of the award, andÂ 
(3) be interested in a Ph.D. granting program in a behavioral or biomedical field (please note this program is notÂ for pre-med students with the exception of students committed to M.D./Ph.D. training).Â 
Â Â 
The deadline for the MARC Undergraduate Scholar Application and required Faculty Recommendation Questionnaire, which will be sent directly to the recommender, is Friday, February 2nd, 2024, at 11:59 pm. Students can access the MARC Undergraduate Scholar Application via College Connect.Â After signing onto College Connect with an Emory NetID, students should click on the Application Center to find the MARC Undergraduate Scholar Application under the Undergraduate Research ProgramsÂ category (see below for a graphic).Â

Opportunity
Â 
New Independent Study Course/Extracurricular Activity - Simuvaction on AI 2024
Simulation - Innovation - Action (Simuvaction), hosted by the Consulat General de France in Atlanta, the Emory Center for Ethics, and the Georgia Institute of Technology, is a challenging and stimulating program for 40 university students from diverse international and interdisciplinary backgrounds.Â 
Â 
Over 6 to 8 weeks, students adopt roles such as heads of state, journalists, and lobbyists, engaging in a simulated environment that mirrors the complexities of global AI policy making. The program culminates in a four-day intensive session in Atlanta (March 16 - March 19), where students apply their learning in a high-stakes negotiation scenario in drafting, debating, and adopting a text as if they were members of the Global Partnership on AI.Â 
Â 
Designed to bridge the gap between academic study and real-world policy challenges, Simuvaction is an opportunity for students to not only understand the intricacies of AI ethics but also to raise their voice on a topic which will shape their future.Â 
Â 
The deadline for enrollment is December 15, 2023. Scheduled class dates are January 15 - March 20, 2024. Visit the Simuvaction website for more information or email Vrushali.Thakkar@emory.eduÂ or acourri@emory.eduÂ with your resume for enrollment.
Â 
Submitted by Sandra Ruhlman Smith

DIRECTOR OF UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH PROGRAM IN THE PATHWAY CENTER
Â 
(SUMMER UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH EXPERIENCE)
Â 
This ten-week program offers undergraduates the opportunity to engage in a full-time research experience.Â  They receive a $3500 stipend and are housed for free at Clairmont Campus.Â 
Â 
Students are required to work with a Faculty Mentor, either in-person or virtually, to create a project which they will present at the SURE Symposium which concludes the program.Â 
Â 
For the first time, the URP Office will offer Faculty Mentors in the Arts, Humanities, and Social Sciences generous stipends for their mentorship of undergraduate researchers during the summer in $1500, $2000, and $2500Â increments.Â 
Â 
There is a significant underrepresentation of undergraduate researchers in the Arts, Humanities, and Social Sciences participating in SURE.Â We strongly encourage you to motivate promising students to apply to participate in the next cohort of SURE Researchers in Summer 2024. The application opened on October 31, 2023 and will close on February 4, 2024.
Â 
For your convenience, I have attached fliers which you may disseminate to your classes and faculty to encourage participation. Should you wish for me or a member of my team to promote SURE at a faculty meeting or class, please do not hesitate to email me at drolle@emory.edu. Thank you for your time and consideration.Â

OPPORTUNITYÂ 
Â 
Â 
PhD Studentship Opportunity
Â 
4-year PhD studentship at University of Leicester in collaboration with University of Birmingham and AstraZeneca, for candidates with strong statistical background.
Â 
Title:Â Model and data-driven solutions for regulatory and HTA decision-making to address emerging challenges in drug development in cancer
Supervisors:Â Prof Sylwia BujkiewiczÂ (UoL), Prof Richard Riley (UoB) and Dr Sam Khan (UoL)
Industry partner:Â Dr Daniel Jackson, AstraZeneca

Collaborator:Â Dr Janharpreet Singh (UoL)
This project will tackle methodological challenges occurring at different milestones of drug development process, including regulatory approvals and particularly HTA decision-making by agencies such as NICE, when evaluating new cancer therapies.Â Modern cancer therapies are often targeted to small subsets of patients who harbour a particular biomarker. Survival data from clinical trials evaluating the effectiveness of therapies in a cancer subtype may be limited. You will explore use of other sources of data; based on alternative outcomes, study types or other cancers, which may need to be synthesised efficiently for reliable policy decisions. 
You will apply a range of modern tools from biostatistics (including Bayesian statistics, meta-analysis and survival analysis), epidemiology and data science and develop novel approaches for evaluation of cancer therapies.
This project is part of an exciting collaboration with University of Birmingham and AstraZeneca. You will benefit from an experienced supervisory team with expertise in statistics and oncology and an industry partner. This PhD in Biostatistics will provide you with an opportunity to develop advanced analytical skills, gain insight into drug development and decision-making processes and influence important decisions in healthcare. A suitable candidate will have MSc in Statistics, Medical Statistics or a related discipline.
Â 
See https://eur03.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fmore.bham.ac.uk%2Fmrc-aim%2Fphd-opportunities%2F&data=05%7C01%7Csylwia.bujkiewicz%40leicester.ac.uk%7C3dc05dbfa44849db697908dbf0bc24b9%7Caebecd6a31d44b0195ce8274afe853d9%7C0%7C0%7C638368463077853590%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=gS7m1yB5qg35tR4HV3muMdfYCe1JhBNjFTy9IPL%2FGSs%3D&reserved=0Â for more details.
Â 
Application deadline Friday 12 January 2024.Â Open to UK and international students.
Â 
Webinars for prospective applicants:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Monday 11 December at 18:30 GMTÂ

OPPORTUNITYÂ 
Â

Â 

EU MSCA SHARE-CTD Doctoral Network,
ATTN QTM Seniors 
We are excited to announce the call for applications for the EU MSCA SHARE-CTD Doctoral Network,Â a European Union-funded initiative designed to foster excellence in clinical trial data sharing. This three year program is specially tailored for outstanding students in data science, biostatistics, computer science, medicine, clinical trials, (clinical) epidemiology or related disciplines.
SHARE-CTD is a European doctoral network spanning universities in Berlin, GÃ¶ttingen, Lyon, Munich, Padova, Rennes, Utrecht, Vienna, and Zurich. The program offers a unique opportunity to engage in cutting-edge research focused on the sharing and re-using of clinical trial data, with an emphasis on Open Science.
The projects encompass topics such as:
Data sharing for validation of prognostic and predictive models in clinical trials. Assessing the impact and methodologies of clinical trial data sharing. Innovations in data anonymization, privacy protection, and automated screening tools. Meta-analyses in mental health and cross-design synthesis in health technology assessment. Statistical methods to use historic data to augment clinical trials and evaluating outcome reporting biases.
For further information, see https://www.share-ctd.euÂ and www.nature.com/naturecareers/job/12810214/...
------------------------------Martin PoschCenter for Medical Data ScienceMedical University of Vienna

Â Submitted by Dominick Rolle,Â  PhD, MBA

Â 
Â

Â 
THE MARCUS AUTISM CENTER
The Marcus Autism Center, in conjunction with the Emory University School of Medicine and Children's Healthcare of Atlanta, is offering five fellowships: the Cohen Fellowship in Developmental Social Neuroscience, the Simons Fellowship in Computational Neuroscience, the Louise and Brett Samsky Fellowship in Educational Science and Practice, the Sally Provence Fellowship in Clinical Research, and the ACCESS Fellowship in Implementation Science. 
Students who will receive a bachelor's degree by June 2024 will be eligible for the positions. The fellowships will commence in July 2024, and they are 2 years in duration. Students can find further details here. 
Attached, please find a brochure describing the fellowships. Please feel free to print the brochure and post it in your department. I ask that you let us know that you have received this e-mail and that you forward it, along with the associated brochure, to students in the Department of Quantitative Theory and Methods. 
The Cohen Fellowship in Developmental Social Neuroscience will involve cutting-edge social neuroscience and/or neuroimaging research in infants, toddlers and adolescents. Fellows will work to further the understanding of autism through eye-tracking research, guiding a project from the point of data collection to publication of results. 
The Simons Fellowship in Computational Neuroscience will involve integrating computational strategies with clinical research goals. Fellows will develop methods for the analysis of visual scanning and eye-tracking data, computational models of visual salience, and data visualization techniques, all with the aim of advancing the understanding of autism and efforts at early diagnosis. 
The Louise and Brett Samsky Fellowship in Educational Science and Practice will involve research in educational innovations in autism. Fellows will learn about classroom-based interventions to increase social emotional engagement and inclusion, gaining experiences with observational research methods, practical experience through direct classroom responsibilities, cutting edge intervention research, and implementation science approaches. 
The Sally Provence Fellowship in Clinical Research will select fellows for a two-year training in clinical assessment measures and research methodologies to better understand ASD and related disabilities. 
The ACCESS Fellowship in Implementation Science will select fellows for a two-year training in research focused on community engagement participatory methods, translating evidence-based treatments for autism into community settings, as well as the processes and partnerships that support these efforts. 
Thank you for your help! We look forward to hearing from you. 
Sincerely, Marcus Predoctoral Fellowship Committee

Â The Carnegie Gaither Junior Fellowship, which provides substantive work experience at the Carnegie Endowment in Washington, DC, for students with a serious career interest in international affairs. Junior Fellows live in Washington D.C. for a year after graduation, providing research assistance to scholars working on the Carnegie Endowment programs. Students may have the opportunity to conduct research for books, co-author journal articles and policy papers, participate in meetings with high-level officials, contribute to congressional testimony, and organize briefings attended by scholars, journalists, and government officials. 
Â 
Students apply to a particular program/project, some of which have specific requirements. Here are the programs with requirements:
Â 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Democracy, Conflict, and Governance
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  American Statecraft
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Nuclear Policy
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Technology and International Affairsâ€”Strong writing skills and research skills are essential.
Â 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Middle Eastâ€”Strong reading fluency and the ability to perform academic as well as on-line research in Arabic essential. Strong background in Middle East politics and/or history is a huge plus.
Â 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  International Security and Political Economy [to work with the International Security and South Asia Programs]â€”Quantitative data analysis and GIS skills are required. A strong mathematical background is a plus. An academic background in international relations theory or international political economy along with an interest in military issues is essential.
Â 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Asia Programâ€”Mandarin Chinese language skills are essential. Proficiency in another Asian language is a plus.
Â 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Russia and Eurasiaâ€”Excellent Russian and/or Ukrainian reading skills required.
Â 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Africa Program
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Global Order and Institutions
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Sustainability, Climate and Geopoliticsâ€”Basic data skills (such as helping create graphs or tables for Carnegie publications) are a plus. Applicants should have completed coursework related to sustainability and climate issues.
Â 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Europeâ€”Fluency and the ability to perform research in a European language other than English are a plus. Background knowledge on European politics is essential.

Special Announcement
