MESSAGE FROM IRIS WITH ATLANTA PEDIATRIC CANCER OUTREACH (APCO)
Â 
Â My name is Iris and I am a member of the Atlanta Pediatric Cancer Outreach (APCO) program at Emory. Every year, we host an event on Emory's campus called Haircuts for Hope, where we ask local professional hairstylists to generously donate their time to cut hair for our students so that we can donate it to Children With Hair Loss, a nonprofit organization which makes hair replacements for pediatric cancer patients. We were wondering if you could send this information and our flyer out to your department listserv.
Â 
This yearâ€™s event will be held at the Emory Student Center in N101 on November 13th from 9 am to 4 pm. The haircuts are completely free-of-charge for students, and donations must be at least 8 inches of hair. Hair can be dyed, but it must be freshly washed and healthy. The QR Code for registering for an appointment can be found on the flyer attached.

Population Biology and Evolution of Diseases

See attachment

Â 
Announcement
Â 
BIOL485: Bioinformatics, by Y. Bromberg. Â 3 credits
What this courseÂ IS:
This course is designed to introduce biologists and computer scientists to basic bioinformatics concepts, principles, and techniques within the framework of command-line and web-based databases/tools.
Students that take the course are expected to:
1.Â Â Â Â Â Know how to work in a command-line environment and have a basic understanding of programming/scripting.Â The course includes aÂ briefÂ introduction to writing Python scripts but requires prior understanding of programming concepts.
2.Â Â Â Â Â Have a working understanding of general biology, evolution, biochemistry, and genetics concepts.Â The course includes onlyÂ briefÂ summaries of the necessary bio concepts and requires pre-existing knowledge.
By the end of this course, students will possess a bioinformatics skill set, including an informed vocabulary and knowledge of basic script development, sufficient for a productive collaboration within a multi-disciplined research team.
Â 
What this course ISÂ NOT:
This is NOT an applied methods course; rather, this class is aimed at understanding of underlying algorithms. We will NOT attempt to list all available tools or teach you how to use them. Method selection, along with the corresponding cutoffs, thresholds, and settings, is specific to each and every research project. If you keep up with the class material you will understand the method underpinnings and be able to able to optimize your project choices on your own.
Â 
ThisÂ introÂ course is also NOT intended for advanced computer science students looking to develop algorithmic expertise in bioinformatics.
Â 
Course Objectives
1.Â Â Â Â Â Teach students to cast a biology problem as a bioinformatic problem, provide them with the skills necessary to independently select relevant tools, optimize their settings, and build pipelines to solve the set problem.
2.Â Â Â Â Â Introduce students to the current bioinformatics algorithms/concepts and their implementations and prepare them for more advanced bioinformatics courses.
3.Â Â Â Â Â Teach students a sufficient bioinformatics skill set, including an informed vocabulary and knowledge of basic script development, for productive collaboration within a multi-disciplined research team.
Â

subject: An offer for Students who completed QTM  340
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
Â 
FROM DR. JO GULDI
Â 
Â 
QTM 490R: Research Lab
â€œUsing AI to Assess the Documentary History of Climate Change: A Multidisciplinary Approachâ€
Â 
As carbon and methane emissions shape our shared future, one essential question is how organizations, institutions, and markets are adopting or failing to adopt new regulations and practices for carbon mitigation and adaptation. An enormous number of published texts document the regulatory life of organizations involved with climate change, including the publications the United Nations, the quarterly reports of U.S Corporations, the World Bank Reports, the Building Codes that govern city, county, and state sustainability plans, and the bills passed by nations. 
Â 
To date, few scholars have attempted to deploy AI to inspect this documentary record.Â  As a result, we have little insight into the successes, failures, and promise of initiatives represented by this documentary base. Research in Computer Science by specialists in Natural Language Processing (NLP) and the Digital Humanities (DH), however, hold promising keys for moving from large language models to accurate depictions of historical change in the recent past.
Â 
Our research will apply these new methods to understanding contemporary institutions. We will connect modern white-box methods from Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Digital Humanities (DH) to the data of climate change governance, illuminating the history of official promises and regulation attempts, and allowing researchers to assemble a timeline and critical account of how climate governance has been changing over the past five, ten, and twenty years.Â  
Â 
What will the course be like? In a research lab, we donâ€™t have a set syllabus as in a seminar or lecture series. In lab meetings, student teams plan ambitious projects of understanding, hear from invited experts, plan to seek out specialty knowledge around campus, and present their results for group review.Â  Readings are assigned as students require input to direct their work on a series of interrelated research problems that they work on in teams. The result is that every student participates actively in shaping their own research agenda, with guidance from the professor and other students.
Â 
What will I study? Current research projects include these topics:
-Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The historical analysis of text over time, showing the evolution of political promises, regulation, commodities trends, and technological adaptation across different nations and markets 
-Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Legal issues about corporate and state responsibilityÂ  
-Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Sociological and historical questions about the evolution of institutions and promises in Brazil, Tanzania and Ethiopia and other developing nations, as well as issues about the inclusion of indigenous property rights and political participation 
-Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Statistical inference about relationships between text-based promises and quantitative data on climate change, for instance, electricity bills, satellite data showing rainforest cover,Â  georeferenced carbon emissions, and data about human displacement and conflict, so as to determine where political and corporate promises have been realized 
Â 
What data will I be working with? Databases we are being assembled by students involved with Guldi Lab include these:
	â€¢	The documentary publications of the UN regarding REDD, the governance framework for assessing rainforest governance
	â€¢	EDGAR, quarterly reports of U.S. publicly-listed corporations discussing their investments in climate mitigation technologies as well as their interest in a shifting profile of agricultural products
	â€¢	The MEDIACLOUD database of news stories from major cities as well as the developing world
	â€¢	The reports of the WORLD BANK that govern major investments in the developing world
	â€¢	MUNICODE, a database of building codes from American cities, counties, and states which govern the standard of sustainability to which new buildings must be built
	â€¢	The CONGRESSIONAL RECORD, the annals of debate in the U.S. Congress 
Â 
What does it mean to take a multidisciplinary approach to climate governance? Experts currently advising the Guldi Lab include:
	â€¢	Prof. Fouad Jabber, Professor of Agricultural Engineering, Texas A&M
	â€¢	Dr. Mindy Goldstein, Emory School of Law and Climate Law Clinic
	â€¢	Dr. Kevin McAlister, QTM/Political Science
	â€¢	Mr. Marcelo Santos de Rocha Silva, Engineering Management, UC Merced, a specialist in Brazil, REDD data, and indigenous governance
	â€¢	Dr. Emil Keme, Indigenous Studies, Emory
	â€¢	Dr. Adriana Chira, Department of History, Emory
	â€¢	Prof. Thomas Rogers, Department of History / Environmental Studies, Emory
	â€¢	Dr. Rahul Bhargava, Northeastern University, College of Arts, Media and Design
	â€¢	Dr. Katie McDonough, Digital Historian, Lancaster University
	â€¢	Prof. Ethan Zuckerman, U Mass Amherst, Public Policy, Communication, and Information
	â€¢	Prof. Craig Hadley, QTM, specialist in the sociology of Africa
	â€¢	Dr. Sandeep Soni, QTM, specialist in NLP
	â€¢	The Emory Center for Digital Scholarship (ECDS), Woodruff Library
Â 
Â 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University

(she/her/hers)

What data will I be working with? Databases we are being assembled by students involved with Guldi Lab include these:
	â€¢	The documentary publications of the UN regarding REDD, the governance framework for assessing rainforest governance
	â€¢	EDGAR, quarterly reports of U.S. publicly-listed corporations discussing their investments in climate mitigation technologies as well as their interest in a shifting profile of agricultural products
	â€¢	The MEDIACLOUD database of news stories from major cities as well as the developing world
	â€¢	The reports of the WORLD BANK that govern major investments in the developing world
	â€¢	MUNICODE, a database of building codes from American cities, counties, and states which govern the standard of sustainability to which new buildings must be built
	â€¢	The CONGRESSIONAL RECORD, the annals of debate in the U.S. Congress 
Â 
What does it mean to take a multidisciplinary approach to climate governance? Experts currently advising the Guldi Lab include:
	â€¢	Prof. Fouad Jabber, Professor of Agricultural Engineering, Texas A&M
	â€¢	Dr. Mindy Goldstein, Emory School of Law and Climate Law Clinic
	â€¢	Dr. Kevin McAlister, QTM/Political Science
	â€¢	Mr. Marcelo Santos de Rocha Silva, Engineering Management, UC Merced, a specialist in Brazil, REDD data, and indigenous governance
	â€¢	Dr. Emil Keme, Indigenous Studies, Emory
	â€¢	Dr. Adriana Chira, Department of History, Emory
	â€¢	Prof. Thomas Rogers, Department of History / Environmental Studies, Emory
	â€¢	Dr. Rahul Bhargava, Northeastern University, College of Arts, Media and Design
	â€¢	Dr. Katie McDonough, Digital Historian, Lancaster University
	â€¢	Prof. Ethan Zuckerman, U Mass Amherst, Public Policy, Communication, and Information
	â€¢	Prof. Craig Hadley, QTM, specialist in the sociology of Africa
	â€¢	Dr. Sandeep Soni, QTM, specialist in NLP
	â€¢	The Emory Center for Digital Scholarship (ECDS), Woodruff Library
Â 
Â 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University

You are cordially invited to the roundtable discussion â€œStop Cop Cityâ€: Unpacking the Struggle Over the South River Forest. The roundtable will take place on Thursday, October 26, 6.00-7.30pm, in White Hall room 208. The event is intended to be an informative session. It brings together scholars and activists to discuss intersecting themes surrounding the debate over the South River forest: environmental justice and racism from a historical perspective as well as the recent criminalization of political protest. 
Â 
Four outstanding speakers will walk us through the complex issues surrounding the struggle over the South River forest here in Atlanta, Georgia: Dr. Jacqueline Echols, Board President of the South River Watershed Alliance; Sasha Tycko, PhD student in Anthropology here at Emory University; Jaanaki Radhakrishnan, Emory undergraduate and student representative for Emory's chapter of the "Stop Cop City" movement; and Selena Coppa-Caldera, Emory School of Law JD student and National Lawyers' Guild representative. The panel will be moderated by Dr. Frank Voigt, DAAD-Lecturer at the Department of German Studies.

The Center for RISC at the University of Chicago is hiring Analysts! We are an unconventional nonprofit founded by Dr. Steve Levitt (ofÂ FreakonomicsÂ fame).Â Our goal is to identify and scale unorthodox solutions to some of the worldâ€™s biggest social problems. Our team is advancing the smart use of technology in criminal justice, helping potential organ donors reach donation weight, and modernizing approaches to K-12 education, to name just a few.
Â 
You will join a small team whose backgrounds have included data science, economics, mechanical engineering, and philosophy, and who have worked in tech and venture capital, consulting, and policy. Analysts will be responsible for researching the root causes of various social issues, proposing creative solutions, and piloting those solutions.
Â 
Ideal candidates are curious and resilient self-starters who are excited about our mission and willing to venture off the beaten path. We welcome applicants from all fields of study!Â 
Â 
Application Deadline: ClosesÂ 11:59PM CDT October 12th
Start date:Â January or August 2024, full time
Location: Employees will be expected in our Hyde Park (Chicago) office 2-3 days per week
Salary: $70,000+, commensurate with experience
Work Authorization: RISC does not sponsor H-1B visas, but as a result of our affiliation with the University of Chicago, non-US citizens working at RISC can obtain J1 visas.

My name is Ariya Maskara and I am a Sophomore at Emory University. I am one of the Research coordinators in a student led club called Science Art Wonder (SAW). In SAW, we connect artists with researcherâ€™s and allow the artists to take inspiration from their researcherâ€™s scientific findings and eventually make an art piece based on it. The QTM department is excited to accept applications for the Fall 2023 DataThink program!Â  This semester's DataThink projects will begin in the middle of September and end around the end of the Fall semester.The DataThink program is an 11-week data micro-consulting project hosted out of Emoryâ€™s QTM Department where teams of students are paired up with local non-profits to solve real problems with real data. Each team is led by a professional mentor who will explain the context of the problem and help guide the team through developing a solution. Participants will gain exposure to the world of professional data analytics, working on projects very similar to those that analysts would in their day-to-day work.Students with all kinds of experience levels are encouraged to apply - the DataThink program is intended as an introduction to real-world data science projects!Â Â  That said, selected students will be expected to be able to work with Python (or have a willingness to learn to do so) in order to perform analysis.Â  Above all else, we're looking for students who are passionate about data science and are eager to learn new skills and apply them to real-world problems.Please only apply for the DataThink program if you have the availability to commit roughly 3-4 hours per week over the entire 11 week program to the project.Â  DataThink projects typically have the same workload as a 1 credit hour class (which is to say, more work than just showing up but nowhere near that of a full 3 credit hour class).Â  The quality of the final deliverable and the experience for the other students on your team are contingent on your continued participation, so please be sure that you'll be able to fit this work into your schedule.Selected students will gain experience in the following areas:â€¢Â Â Â Â Â Â  Data Storytellingâ€¢Â Â Â Â Â Â  Insight development for a real clientâ€¢Â Â Â Â Â Â  Professional experience to build oneâ€™s resumeâ€¢Â Â Â Â Â Â  In-demand data technical skills such as Python, SQL, and data visualization toolsâ€¢Â Â Â Â Â Â  Collaboration and teamwork in the data spaceThis semester we are proud to partner on projects with the following organizations:â€¢Â Â Â Â Â Â  Science for Georgiaâ€¢Â Â Â Â Â Â  Community Foundation for Greater Atlantaâ€¢Â Â Â Â Â Â  Better Business Bureau (Atlanta & NE Georgia)â€¢Â Â Â Â Â Â  Enterprise Community Partners
Interested student should submit their application here by end of day on Friday, September 8th.Â  If the embedded link does not work, you can access the application by pastingÂ https://forms.office.com/r/wWRcQUydkxÂ into your browser. Â Students will be informed of their application status soon after this deadline.

Announcement
The QTM department is excited to accept applications for the Fall 2023 DataThink program!Â  
Â 
This semester's DataThink projects will begin in the middle of September and end around the end of the Fall semester.
Â 
The DataThink program is an 11-week data micro-consulting project hosted out of Emoryâ€™s QTM Department where teams of students are paired up with local non-profits to solve real problems with real data. Each team is led by a professional mentor who will explain the context of the problem and help guide the team through developing a solution. Participants will gain exposure to the world of professional data analytics, working on projects very similar to those that analysts would in their day-to-day work.
Â 
Students with all kinds of experience levels are encouraged to apply - the DataThink program is intended as an introduction to real-world data science projects!Â  Â That said, selected students will be expected to be able to work with Python (or have a willingness to learn to do so) in order to perform analysis.Â  Above all else, we're looking for students who are passionate about data science and are eager to learn new skills and apply them to real-world problems.Â 
Â 
Please only apply for the DataThink program if you have the availability to commit roughly 3-4 hours per week over the entire 11 week program to the project.Â Â DataThink projects typically have the same workload as a 1 credit hour class (which is to say, more work than just showing up but nowhere near that of a full 3 credit hour class).Â  The quality of the final deliverable and the experience for the other students on your team are contingent on your continued participation, so please be sure that you'll be able to fit this work into your schedule.
Â 
Selected students will gain experience in the following areas:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Data Storytelling
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Insight development for a real client
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Professional experience to build oneâ€™s resume
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In-demand data technical skills such as Python, SQL, and data visualization tools
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Collaboration and teamwork in the data space
This semester we are proud to partner on projects with the following organizations:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Science for Georgia

Interested student should submit their applicationÂ https://forms.office.com/r/wWRcQUydkx.Â by end of day on Friday, September 8th.Â  Students will be informed of their application status soon after this deadline.

Opportunity
Â 
Undergraduate Research Assistant Position: 2023-2024 Academic Year
Emory-Einstein TB/HIV Research Group
Focus:
Join an engaging research team working on cutting-edge projects in the field of infectious diseases, with a specific focus on drug-resistant tuberculosis, latent tuberculosis, and global health.
Emory-Einstein TB/HIV Research Group Profile:
The Emory-Einstein TB/HIV Research Group, situated within the Departments of Epidemiology and Global Health at the Rollins School of Public Health, Emory University, is a highly regarded academic research and training program specializing in TB, HIV, and Global Health. Our projects are recognized both nationally and internationally, and we closely collaborate with leading organizations, including the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Columbia University, Vanderbilt University, Yale University, Brown University, University of KwaZulu-Natal (South Africa), Centre for the AIDS Programme of Research in South Africa, National Center of TB and Lung Disease (Georgia), Aurum Institute (South Africa), Dekalb County Board of Health, and Fulton County Board of Health.
Position Profile:
We are seeking exceptional undergraduate students with interests in public health, epidemiology, infectious diseases, quantitative sciences, and global health for the 2023-2024 academic school year with the possibility of extending the position into subsequent terms. We welcome applications from students enrolled in quantitative science, public health, biology, and other science-related degree programs. Ideal candidates possess a collaborative mindset, enthusiasm for global health, attention to detail, excellent interpersonal skills, and an eagerness to develop new skills. As an undergraduate research assistant, your responsibilities may include:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Transcribe lab results accurately from source documents to case report forms (CRFs)
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Data entry into REDCap databases
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Conduct data quality control (QC) checks
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Review data compare and logic check reports to resolve data discrepancies
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Organize study participant binders and maintain electronic archives of CRFs
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Prepare project-related team meeting agendas and participate in meetings
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Maintain regular communication with internal staff regarding study activities and data queries
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Complete additional duties as assigned by the Project Coordinator, Data Manager, and Director of the research program.
Qualifications
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Enrolled in an undergraduate-level program at Emory University
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Strong attention to detail and organizational skills
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Knowledge of and/or familiarity with data management tools and software (e.g., REDCap, SAS)
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Excellent interpersonal skills and ability to work collaboratively in a team environment
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Enthusiastic, proactive, and self-motivated
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Previous experience, particularly in the field of infectious diseases or quantitative sciences, is a plus
How to Apply
Interested applicants should email Adrian King (Adrian.king@emory.edu) directly.Â  Please attach your most recent resume and a cover letter describing your interests, skills, experiences, and relevant course work related to quantitative sciences, public health, and/or infectious diseases.

Opportunity
Announcement from Carolyn Han with 180 Degrees Consulting
I'm the co-president for 180 Degrees Consulting, a social impact-focused consulting club. We work with nonprofits across the world, in areas like clean energy, gender equality, and healthcare, on projects relating to strategy, tech, marketing, and expansion.One of 180's goals this year is to increase our non-business school members. While consulting is often associated with business, we firmly believe that students from the College of Arts and Sciences bring unique skillsets and perspectives to the table. In fact, 180's current and past exec board has had students studying Economics, Human Health, Math, and even French. This is why we wish to reach out to and encourage QTM students to apply. 
180 isn't looking for business-ready consultants: we want students who are creative, critical thinkers, and passionate about social impact. On Tuesday, September 5th, at 5:30pm, we will be hosting an info session specifically for college students at White Hall, room 103. In this session, we'll be demystifying consulting for non-BBA students. 
Again, 180 would truly love to have students of "nontraditional" majors join the club.

subject: SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT 
Â 
Â 
Â 
The QTM department is now accepting applications for QTM undergraduate research fellows for the Fall 2023 semester.
Â 
The goal of the QTM fellows program is to introduce students to the wide array of research opportunities that exist across curricular areas that leverage the skills that they learn in their QTM classes. Â As a student researcher, you will have the opportunity to assist in a faculty-led research project and receive mentorship regarding graduate school and career opportunities. Â Historically, students who work with a faculty member for one semester choose to extend their time on the project beyond the first semester which leads to long-term research collaborations.
Students who participate in the QTM fellows programÂ will be enrolled in a 3 credit hour research class (QTM 499R). Â This means that you can expect to commit roughly 10 hours per week (on average) to research activities. Â The requirements for this class are simply to work with a faculty mentor on research activities. Â To monitor student participation and progress, your faculty mentors will be asked to fill out two quick surveys (one at midterm time and one at the end of the semester) to rate your performance up until that point. Â Grades will be given as a function of the responses to these surveys and a short written summary of your research work turned in at the end of the semester.
Â 
Students who would like to apply for a QTM fellowship should fill out one of the two applications below:Â 
Â 
	â€¢	If you already have a faculty advisor from any department across Emoryâ€™s campus who has committed to serve as your research advisor for the semester, fill out this application.Â 
	â€¢	If you would like to be placed in the pool of students to be matched with a faculty advisor looking for an undergraduate research assistant, fill out this application.Â 
Â 
Applicants who already have a committed research advisor should submit their application no less than 3 days before the end of the add/drop/swap period in the semester.Â  Applications submittedÂ after this time will be rejected and you will not be enrolled in QTM 499R.Â  This application requires a signed and dated letter from the faculty advisor statingÂ that they are willing to serve in this capacityÂ for the semester.Â  Applications that do not include this letter will not be reviewed and you will not be allowed to enroll in the research course for credit.Â  Upon completion of the application, the letter will be reviewedÂ and the Director of Undergraduate Research will choose whether or not to approve enrollment in QTM 499R.Â  Students will be informed of the status of their applications as soon as possible.Â 
Â 
Applicants who are applying to be placed in the pool of research assistants that will be matched with faculty advisors should complete the application close to the beginning of each semester.Â  Applications will be reviewed and matched on a rolling basis with the first wave of matches occurring on the first Friday of classes in the new semester.Â  Further applications will be reviewed and matched, asÂ possible, until the end of the semesterâ€™s add/drop/swap period.Â 
Â 
When matching students to research assistant roles, preference will be given to students closer to graduation and fitÂ within each projectâ€™s substantive area will be considered.Â  Unfortunately, the number of applications for research assistant roles will far exceed the number of available positions.Â  It is possible that matches will not work out in the initial stageÂ and weâ€™ll revisit the applicant pool to fill all available positions.Â  All students will be notified of their applicationâ€™s status atÂ the end of the add/drop/swap period.

If you have any questions, please reach out to QTM's Director of Undergraduate Research - Dr. Kevin McAlister (kevin.mcalister@emory.edu).Â 
Â 
Best, 
Â 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University
Email: shanna9@emory.edu | 470-620-7981
(she/her/hers)

Opportunity

Frontiers of Statistics Symposiumnationalacademies.org
Â 
Frontiers of Statistics: National Academies Virtual Symposium
Statistics is critically important for research ranging from medicine to engineering, and new advances provide exciting opportunities. Â 
Explore the frontiers of statistics and discuss the future of the discipline at an upcoming National Academies' virtual symposium on the FrontiersÂ of Statistics June 22, 2023 from 2-5pm ET.Â 
During the symposium, speakers will engage in a forward-looking discussion about the state of the statistical sciences and emerging opportunities for the discipline and its stakeholders. Panelists will highlight cutting-edge research in statistics as well as the importance of statistical research and training for other disciplines. Â The panel discussion will explore developments in machine learning and the statistical questions that motivate its growth, ways to foster interactions with domains that are enriched by the statistical sciences, and future areas of exploration for statistical research.
Register to attend online at:Â events.nationalacademies.org/...
Â

Submitted by Sandra Ruhlman Smith

Â 
Â 
Â 
Announcement
Â 
Message from Michael Garcia, Program Director at AI Innovators 
Â 
AI Innovators an educational program committed to empowering the next generation of social science researchers to learn and apply artificial intelligence to push the frontiers of their fields. As generative AI technologies make an impact across disciplines, the possibilities for students to apply AI to projects such as identifying pockets of unregistered voters and scanning millions of legal documents for relevant information are endless.
Phil Bell, a Harvard Education School alum and previous classroom instructor who teaches AI and Social Sciences at Inspirit, has developed novel approaches to linguistic analysis to mitigate bias in news reporting! Weâ€™d love to make the 2023 AI Innovation Fellowship in Interdisciplinary Data Science available to students.
Â 
We believe strong data analysis and AI skills improve the quality of research and job preparation for social sciences students. Developed and taught by MIT and Stanford graduates, the AI and Political Science/Law Innovation Fellowship in summer 2023 offers students the opportunity to gain an endorsed technical skillset and complete a shareable AI project to advance their research and career ambitions.
Â 
Artificial Intelligence and Political Science/Law Summer Program by Stanford GraduatesThe AI Innovators program offers a 25-hour education experience in Interdisciplinary Data Science which equips students in the arts with in-demand skills like data analysis in Python, statistics in R, and machine learning. Leveraging these new tools, students build out a professional portfolio with capstone projects such as news bias detection and algorithmic justice that draw on their unique interests. Please find more information about relevant projects here and apply here. Feel free to contact program coordinator Jared at programs@inspiritinnovator.com with any questions. 
Â 
Â 
Submitted by Michael Garcia
